contentrichtext.text: [[Image:LittleArmeniaPrincipality of AntiochTripoli.jpg|thumb|Bohemond V ruled over Antioch and Tripoli (green), and was in conflict with [[Cilician Armenia]] (blue) until shortly before his death.]] '''Bohemond V of Antioch''' (1199âˆ’1252)<ref name=runciman-278>Runciman, ''History of the Crusades''', vol. III, p. 278</ref> was ruler of the [[Principality of Antioch]], a [[crusader state]], from 1233 to his death. He was simultaneously [[Count of Tripoli]]. Bohemond V was the son of [[Bohemund IV of Antioch]] and [[Plaisance of Gibelet]]. Like his father before him, Bohemond had a notorious dislike for the [[Knights Hospitaller]] and the neighbouring [[Armenian Kingdom of Cilicia|Kingdom of Armenia]], preferring an alliance with the [[Knights Templar]]. Peace with Armenia was assured only shortly before his death, with the mediation of [[Louis IX of France]]. In 1225, Bohemond was married to Princess [[Alice of Cyprus|Adela]] (also known as ''Alice of Jerusalem''),<ref>{{cite web |url= http://fmg.ac/Projects/MedLands/JERUSALEM.htm#AlixM1HuguesICyprusM2BohemondVAntioch |title=Medieval Lands Project: JERUSALEM, KINGS - D. KINGS OF JERUSALEM 1192-1225 (COUNTS of CHAMPAGNE) |author= |month=April |year=2009 |language= |accessdate=04-07-2009 }}</ref> Queen Dowager of [[Cyprus]] and [[Jerusalem]], whom he divorced and had the marriage annulled after July 5, 1227, most likely in 1229, without issue. His second marriage was in 1235 to Luciana (Lucienne) di Segni, a great-niece of [[Pope Innocent III]]. He had two children: * [[Plaisance of Antioch]], a daughter who became the third wife of King [[Henry I of Cyprus]] in 1251<ref>Runciman, p. 278. "Bohemond V died in January 1252, leaving two children, a daughter, Plaisance, who had married a few months before, as his third wife, the childless King Henry of Cyprus."</ref> * [[Bohemond VI of Antioch]] Bohemond V died in January 1252. Since his son and successor was only 15 at the time, he succeeded under the regency of the [[Dowager Princess]], Luciana. However, Luciana never left [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]], and instead handed over the government of the principality to her Roman relatives. This made her unpopular, so the young Bohemond VI gained the approval of King [[Louis IX of France]], who was on Crusade at the time, to get permission from Pope [[Innocent IV]] to come of age a few months early.<ref name=runciman-278/> ==Notes== {{Reflist}} ==References== * {{cite book|author=Richard, Jean|isbn= 978-0-521-62566-1|year=1999|title=The Crusades: c. 1071-c. 1291|publisher=Cambridge University Press|authorlink= Jean Richard (historian)}} {{start box}} {{succession box | before=[[Bohemond IV of Antioch|Bohemund IV]] | title=[[Prince of Antioch]]<br>[[Count of Tripoli]] | years=1233–1252 | after=[[Bohemond VI of Antioch|Bohemond VI]]}} {{end box}} {{Antioch Monarchs}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Bohemond V, Prince Of Antioch | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1252 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bohemond V, Prince Of Antioch}} [[Category:1252 deaths]] [[Category:Counts of Tripoli|Bohemond II]] [[Category:Princes of Antioch]] [[Category:Roman Catholic monarchs]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] {{euro-noble-stub}}
